newsitem.title: FINLAND: Finland's bizarre Elvis lover serenades summit.
newsitem.headline: Finland's bizarre Elvis lover serenades summit.

text.p: A bespectacled Finnish professor with a cult following and a bizarre hobby made a mark on the U.S.-Russian summit on Friday, dedicating his latest recording of Elvis Presley hits in Latin to "Boris and Bill".

Professor Jukka Ammondt, a specialist in the history of literature from the University of Jyvaskyla, dedicated songs like "Glauci Calcei" (Blue Suede Shoes) "Mella Fella" (Money Honey) and "Ursus Taddeus" (Teddy Bear) to U.S. President Bill Clinton and Russian President Boris Yeltsin.

Belting out his antique versions of Elvis in a Helsinki nightclub, he dedicated "Quate, crepa, rota" (Shake, Rattle and Roll) to Yeltsin and said the 66-year-old Kremlin chief was a "rocking grandfather".
And he suggested Clinton should sing "Ne Saevias" (Don't be Cruel) to his Russian counterpart, in the spirit of partnership evident at the Helsinki summit.
Ammondt, who refuses to give his age although he appears to be around 50, insisted the combination of Latin and rock 'n roll was particularly appropriate for U.S.-Russian summitry.
"Latin used to unite the western world, and today rock unifies the western world," he said.

The professor, who has also recorded Latin versions of tango songs, has been described as "the most well-known Finn in America" after he recently turned up with his songs in Memphis, Elvis's birthplace and still a shrine to his fans.
Sporting a white suit with scarlet cummerband and black patent shoes, he hopped and gyrated amid flashing disco lights and stage-mist, belting his way through the classics of rock.
For wheelchair-bound Clinton, who injured his knee last week, and Yeltsin, who is recovering from illness, the best title may be "Nunc distrahor" (All Shook Up).
One line: "Manibus tremo, tremo genibus/Ambobus non sto nunc pedibus", translates as "My hands are shaky and my knees are weak/I can't seem to stand on my own two feet"
